trans-unit.source: Deploy Azure Resources by Using a Template
trans-unit.target: Deploy Azure Resources by Using a Template

trans-unit.source: Learn to use some of the available clients in the Azure Resource Management Library to deploy a virtual machine, virtual network, and storage account
trans-unit.target: Learn to use some of the available clients in the Azure Resource Management Library to deploy a virtual machine, virtual network, and storage account

trans-unit.source: Deploy Azure Resources Using .NET Libraries and a Template
trans-unit.target: Deploy Azure Resources Using .NET Libraries and a Template

trans-unit.source: By using resource groups and templates, you're able to manage all of the resources that support your application together.
trans-unit.target: By using resource groups and templates, you're able to manage all of the resources that support your application together.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use some of the available clients in the Azure Resource Management Library and how to build a template to deploy a virtual machine, virtual network, and storage account.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use some of the available clients in the Azure Resource Management Library and how to build a template to deploy a virtual machine, virtual network, and storage account.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial you also need:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial you also need:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: [Windows Management Framework 3.0](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=34595) or [Windows Management Framework 4.0](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=40855)
trans-unit.target: [Windows Management Framework 3.0](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=34595) or [Windows Management Framework 4.0](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=40855)

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: It takes about 30 minutes to do these steps.
trans-unit.target: It takes about 30 minutes to do these steps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Add an application to Azure AD and set permissions
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Add an application to Azure AD and set permissions

trans-unit.source: To use Azure AD to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager, an application must be added to the Default Directory.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure AD to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager, an application must be added to the Default Directory.

trans-unit.source: Do the following to add an application:
trans-unit.target: Do the following to add an application:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt, and then run this command:
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt, and then run this command:

trans-unit.source: Set the Azure account that you want to use for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Set the Azure account that you want to use for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Run this command and enter the credentials for your subscription when prompted:
trans-unit.target: Run this command and enter the credentials for your subscription when prompted:

trans-unit.source: Replace {password} in the following command with the one that you want to use and then run it to create the application:
trans-unit.target: Replace {password} in the following command with the one that you want to use and then run it to create the application:

trans-unit.source: Record the value the ApplicationId value in the response from the previous step.
trans-unit.target: Record the value the ApplicationId value in the response from the previous step.

trans-unit.source: You will need it later in this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You will need it later in this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: Create an AD application
trans-unit.target: Create an AD application

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can also find the application identifier in the client id field of the application in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can also find the application identifier in the client id field of the application in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Replace {application-id} with the identifier that you just recorded and then create the service principal for the application:
trans-unit.target: Replace {application-id} with the identifier that you just recorded and then create the service principal for the application:

trans-unit.source: Set the permission to use the application:
trans-unit.target: Set the permission to use the application:

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create the Visual Studio project, the template file, and the parameters file
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create the Visual Studio project, the template file, and the parameters file

trans-unit.source: Create the template file
trans-unit.target: Create the template file

trans-unit.source: An Azure Resource Manager Template makes it possible for you to deploy and manage Azure resources together by using a JSON description of the resources and associated deployment parameters.
trans-unit.target: An Azure Resource Manager Template makes it possible for you to deploy and manage Azure resources together by using a JSON description of the resources and associated deployment parameters.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click **File** > **New** > **Project**.
trans-unit.target: Click **File** > **New** > **Project**.

trans-unit.source: In **Templates** > **Visual C#**, select **Console Application**, enter the name and location of the project, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In **Templates** > **Visual C#**, select **Console Application**, enter the name and location of the project, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project name in Solution Explorer, and then click **Add** > **New Item**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project name in Solution Explorer, and then click **Add** > **New Item**.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item window, select **Text File**, enter *VirtualMachineTemplate.json* for the name, and then click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item window, select **Text File**, enter *VirtualMachineTemplate.json* for the name, and then click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Open the VirtualMachineTemplate.json file and then add the opening and closing brackets, the required schema element, and the required contentVersion element:
trans-unit.target: Open the VirtualMachineTemplate.json file and then add the opening and closing brackets, the required schema element, and the required contentVersion element:

trans-unit.source: [Parameters](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#parameters) are not always required, but they make template management easier.
trans-unit.target: [Parameters](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#parameters) are not always required, but they make template management easier.

trans-unit.source: They describe the type of the value, the default value if needed, and possibly the allowed values of the parameter.
trans-unit.target: They describe the type of the value, the default value if needed, and possibly the allowed values of the parameter.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, the parameters that are used to create a virtual machine, a storage account, and a virtual network are added to the template.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, the parameters that are used to create a virtual machine, a storage account, and a virtual network are added to the template.

trans-unit.source: Add the parameters element and its child elements after the contentVersion element:
trans-unit.target: Add the parameters element and its child elements after the contentVersion element:

trans-unit.source: [Variables](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#variables) can be used in a template to specify values that may change frequently or values that need to be created from a combination of parameter values.
trans-unit.target: [Variables](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#variables) can be used in a template to specify values that may change frequently or values that need to be created from a combination of parameter values.

trans-unit.source: Add the variables element after the parameters section:
trans-unit.target: Add the variables element after the parameters section:

trans-unit.source: [Resources](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#resources) such as the virtual machine, the virtual network, and the storage account are defined next in the template.
trans-unit.target: [Resources](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md#resources) such as the virtual machine, the virtual network, and the storage account are defined next in the template.

trans-unit.source: Add the resources section after the variables section:
trans-unit.target: Add the resources section after the variables section:

trans-unit.source: Save the template file that you created.
trans-unit.target: Save the template file that you created.

trans-unit.source: Create the parameters file
trans-unit.target: Create the parameters file

trans-unit.source: To specify values for the resource parameters that were defined in the template, you create a parameters file that contains the values and submit it to the Resource Manager with the template.
trans-unit.target: To specify values for the resource parameters that were defined in the template, you create a parameters file that contains the values and submit it to the Resource Manager with the template.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project name in Solution Explorer, and then click **Add**, and then **New Item**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project name in Solution Explorer, and then click **Add**, and then **New Item**.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item window, select **Text File**, enter *Parameters.json* for the Name, and then click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item window, select **Text File**, enter *Parameters.json* for the Name, and then click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Open the parameters.json file and then add the following JSON content:
trans-unit.target: Open the parameters.json file and then add the following JSON content:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Image vhd names change regularly in the image gallery, so you need to get a current image name to deploy the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Image vhd names change regularly in the image gallery, so you need to get a current image name to deploy the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: To do this, see [Manage Images Windows using Windows PowerShell](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn790330.aspx), and then replace {source-image-name} with the name of the vhd file that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: To do this, see [Manage Images Windows using Windows PowerShell](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn790330.aspx), and then replace {source-image-name} with the name of the vhd file that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: For example, "a699494373c04fc0bc8f2bb1389d6106__Windows-Server-2012-R2-201412.01-en.us-127GB.vhd".
trans-unit.target: For example, "a699494373c04fc0bc8f2bb1389d6106__Windows-Server-2012-R2-201412.01-en.us-127GB.vhd".

trans-unit.source: Replace {subscription-id} with the identifier of your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Replace {subscription-id} with the identifier of your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Save the parameters file that you created.
trans-unit.target: Save the parameters file that you created.

trans-unit.source: The template file and the parameters file are accessed by Azure Resource Manager from an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The template file and the parameters file are accessed by Azure Resource Manager from an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: To put the files in storage, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To put the files in storage, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Open Server Explorer and navigate to the container in your storage account where you want to place the file.
trans-unit.target: Open Server Explorer and navigate to the container in your storage account where you want to place the file.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, the container where the template is located is named templates.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, the container where the template is located is named templates.

trans-unit.source: In the upper-right corner of the templates container pane, click the Upload Blob icon, browse to the VirtualMachineTemplate.json file that you created, and then click **Open**.
trans-unit.target: In the upper-right corner of the templates container pane, click the Upload Blob icon, browse to the VirtualMachineTemplate.json file that you created, and then click **Open**.

trans-unit.source: Click the Upload Blob icon again, browse to the Parameters.json file that you created, and then click **Open**.
trans-unit.target: Click the Upload Blob icon again, browse to the Parameters.json file that you created, and then click **Open**.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Install the libraries
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Install the libraries

trans-unit.source: NuGet packages are the easiest way to install the libraries that you need to finish this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: NuGet packages are the easiest way to install the libraries that you need to finish this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You must install the Azure Resource Management Library and the Azure Active Directory Authentication Library.
trans-unit.target: You must install the Azure Resource Management Library and the Azure Active Directory Authentication Library.

trans-unit.source: To get these libraries in Visual Studio, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To get these libraries in Visual Studio, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click **Manage NuGet Packages**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click **Manage NuGet Packages**.

trans-unit.source: Type *Active Directory* in the search box, click **Install** for the Active Directory Authentication Library package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type *Active Directory* in the search box, click **Install** for the Active Directory Authentication Library package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the page, select **Include Prerelease**.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the page, select **Include Prerelease**.

trans-unit.source: Type *Azure Resource Management* in the search box, click **Install** for the Microsoft Azure Resource Management Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type *Azure Resource Management* in the search box, click **Install** for the Microsoft Azure Resource Management Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to start using the libraries to create your application.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to start using the libraries to create your application.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create the credentials that are used to authenticate requests
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create the credentials that are used to authenticate requests

trans-unit.source: Now that the Azure Active Directory application is created and the authentication library has been installed, you format the application information into credentials that are used to authenticate requests to the Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Now that the Azure Active Directory application is created and the authentication library has been installed, you format the application information into credentials that are used to authenticate requests to the Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Do the following:
trans-unit.target: Do the following:

trans-unit.source: Open the Program.cs file for the project that you created, and then add the following using statements to the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Open the Program.cs file for the project that you created, and then add the following using statements to the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to get the token that is needed to create the credentials:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to get the token that is needed to create the credentials:

trans-unit.source: Replace {application-id} with the application identifier that you recorded earlier, {password} with the password that you chose for the AD application, and {tenant-id} with the tenant identifier for your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Replace {application-id} with the application identifier that you recorded earlier, {password} with the password that you chose for the AD application, and {tenant-id} with the tenant identifier for your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can find the tenant id by running Get-AzureSubscription.
trans-unit.target: You can find the tenant id by running Get-AzureSubscription.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method in the Program.cs file to create the credentials:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method in the Program.cs file to create the credentials:

trans-unit.source: Save the Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Save the Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Add the code to deploy the template
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Add the code to deploy the template

trans-unit.source: Resources are always deployed from a template to a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Resources are always deployed from a template to a resource group.

trans-unit.source: You use the [ResourceGroup](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.management.resources.models.resourcegroup.aspx) and the [ResourceManagementClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.management.resources.resourcemanagementclient.aspx) classes to create the resource group that the resources are deployed to.
trans-unit.target: You use the [ResourceGroup](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.management.resources.models.resourcegroup.aspx) and the [ResourceManagementClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.azure.management.resources.resourcemanagementclient.aspx) classes to create the resource group that the resources are deployed to.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to create the resource group:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to create the resource group:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to deploy the resources to the resource group by using the template that you defined:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to deploy the resources to the resource group by using the template that you defined:

trans-unit.source: Replace {storage-account-name} with the name of the account where you previously placed the files.
trans-unit.target: Replace {storage-account-name} with the name of the account where you previously placed the files.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Add the code to delete the resources
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Add the code to delete the resources

trans-unit.source: Because you are charged for resources used in Azure, it is always a good practice to delete resources that are no longer needed.
trans-unit.target: Because you are charged for resources used in Azure, it is always a good practice to delete resources that are no longer needed.

trans-unit.source: You don’t need to delete each resource separately from a resource group.
trans-unit.target: You don’t need to delete each resource separately from a resource group.

trans-unit.source: You can delete the resource group and all of its resources will automatically be deleted.
trans-unit.target: You can delete the resource group and all of its resources will automatically be deleted.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to delete the resource group:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to delete the resource group:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Step 7: Run the console application
trans-unit.target: Step 7: Run the console application

trans-unit.source: To run the console application, click **Start** in Visual Studio, and then sign in to Azure AD using the same username and password that you use with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: To run the console application, click **Start** in Visual Studio, and then sign in to Azure AD using the same username and password that you use with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Press **Enter** after each status code is returned to create each resource.
trans-unit.target: Press **Enter** after each status code is returned to create each resource.

trans-unit.source: After the virtual machine is created, do the next step before pressing Enter to delete all of the resources.
trans-unit.target: After the virtual machine is created, do the next step before pressing Enter to delete all of the resources.

trans-unit.source: It should take about 5 minutes for this console application to run completely from start to finish.
trans-unit.target: It should take about 5 minutes for this console application to run completely from start to finish.

trans-unit.source: Before you press Enter to start deleting resources, you could take a few minutes to verify the creation of the resources in the Azure preview portal before you delete them.
trans-unit.target: Before you press Enter to start deleting resources, you could take a few minutes to verify the creation of the resources in the Azure preview portal before you delete them.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the Audit Logs in the Azure preview portal to see the status of the resources:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the Audit Logs in the Azure preview portal to see the status of the resources:

trans-unit.source: Create an AD application
trans-unit.target: Create an AD application
